question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course helped me with self-awareness and to see the value in business beyond numbers. I learned a lot about the soft skills that go into operating a good business, which are just as important or more as understanding numbers. We learned about leadership strategies, leadership characteristics, how to work well in a team, how to deal with adversity, technology, etc... these lessons all helped me think about what I need to improve for my future career.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One of the most transformative concepts I learned was systems thinking, particularly the use of the Iceberg Model. This framework taught me to analyze problems at multiple levels—moving from surface-level events to identifying underlying patterns, structures, and mental models that drive behavior. For example, instead of focusing solely on team conflicts as isolated incidents, I now consider how organizational structures or unspoken norms might contribute to recurring issues. This deeper way of thinking has helped me approach challenges with a more strategic mindset.
This course emphasized that effective leadership begins with self-awareness. Through reflection exercises and discussions, I learned to assess my strengths, values, and blind spots. For instance, I realized that while I’m strong at goal-setting, I need to improve my listening skills to foster better collaboration. Recognizing these traits has helped me align my leadership style with my values and the needs of those I work with, making me a more empathetic and intentional leader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I learned were how to present, how to write, and how to work in a team. There are two required presentations for this course. One of them is a group project in which you complete assigned readings and then prepare a presentation to teach the class. This was a great way to make sure that we understood what we were learning. The second presentation was a project with the same group in which you apply all the topics we learned to analyze a company that we chose at the beginning of the semester. Both of these projects were a great way to learn how to work on a team. We had to learn how to coordinate our schedules, delegate roles, create presentations, synthesize information, and so much more. We also had four major written assignments throughout the semester and a weekly written assignment. The four major assignments were very interesting and fun to complete because of how creative they were. They helped me understand the topics we were learning on a deeper level and were a great way to practice concise writing. Each Sunday we had to submit a question about anything covered in class throughout the week and we had to respond to two students' questions. An AI model graded our responses. This was also a great activity because it caused us to reflect on the course on a weekly basis and try to think of open-ended questions. It was a great and easy way to stimulate conversation!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course offered a unique opportunity for real world experience in marketing which I found incredibly useful. I had the opportunity to learn specific marketing methods and skills, and then apply them to a semester long campaign with a real company which added value to my work. One of the key skills I learned was how to take ideas from various group members and combine them to create a cohesive project and execute on our vision. Secondly, I learned how to apply methods learned during class presentations and from the textbook to actual work. Application of these lessons was really useful. Finally, I learned how to think outside the box, especially in terms of guerrilla marketing. I was able to creatively build on ideas while expanding on my teams message which was very gratifying.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to build a full marketing strategy from segmentation and targeting to positioning and execution, using real frameworks that are used in industry. I also learned how to analyze customer value through concepts like customer lifetime value and emotional based marketing, which are tools I’ll definitely carry forward in product management. I also gained insight into branding and storytelling as a competitive advantage, especially useful in building compelling products and campaigns.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.Personal Seat Licenses: you pay a fee to buy tickets in the first place ($8,000 for Duke), and then you can pay for individual tickets after
2. Winner’s Curse: when a person is trying to buy a team, or a team is trying to sign/recruit a player, you end up paying too much money simply because you tried to win
3. Rozelle Rule: teams had to compensate each other when signing a free agent (it became a trade)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Comprehensive Understanding of the Sports Industry: This course provided a thorough overview of the business side of sports, from finance and valuation to sponsorship, marketing, and labor issues. I gained a deeper understanding of how teams, leagues, and athletes interact with each other and the media.Finance Perspective on Sports: I learned how to analyze the financial viability of sports organizations, looking at things like player salaries, team valuations, and sponsorship deals. It gave me the tools to critically evaluate the business aspects of sports beyond just watching the games.Real-World Applications: Through case studies, guest speakers, and current events discussions, I learned to connect classroom concepts with real-world scenarios. This helped me understand how industry trends, such as media coverage and public funding for stadiums, shape the sports landscape.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We reflected upon the variety of skills and lessons we learned through all of our MMS courses at Duke. Specifically, we honed our personal finance skills, brainstormed personal and professional goals, and learned about a variety of unconventional paths.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned more than I expected—both in terms of valuable academic knowledge and life skills that no other class, public or private school, has provided. Three specific things I learned are:Navigating Financials: The course gave me a strong foundation in understanding markets and management, which is crucial for any future career. I gained skills that allow me to analyze and navigate financial data, a skill I hadn't fully developed before.Emotional Intelligence: I learned how to manage and understand emotions, both my own and others’, which is essential for effective leadership and decision-making in any setting. This was a huge takeaway that applies beyond just business or academics.Life Outside of Our Experiences: This course also broadened my perspective on life beyond what we’ve experienced over the past 20-plus years. It taught me how to think critically about the world, approach challenges with a more mature mindset, and adapt to the complexities that come with adulthood.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about communication and reaching out. The assignment that required interviewing 4 duke alums was hugely helpful and a new experience for me, who has crippling anxiety and has been avoiding networking + meeting new people (lol). We not only discussed key strategies and helpful phrases, goals, and questions that can facilitate the interview process, but also had continuous check-ins with both the class as a whole as well as our smaller groups, which provided moral support and community guidance. This class also delved into personal finance, which I can always learn more in and was HUGELY appreciated and helpful. I've also never made a career plan or financial plan before, often flying by the seat of my pants as I progress through life. The intentionality and careful thought required for these assignments and practices was really grounding and helpful, and eased worries about the future.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Though I liked some of the books we read, the class was not engaging at all. Every city assignment was analyzing municipal finance and it was extremely repetitive and hard to understand. Almost every paper we did was just summarizing something, there was no creativity or reflection. I get absolutely nothing from writing a summary. Also, we never learned anything in class- he just had us present extremely long and boring summary presentation the whole time. He's a nice person, but not a good teacher: he never used any visuals or powerpoints, he would talk at us and go on random tangents for 45 minutes, and didn't give us any breaks even though it was a 2.5 hour night class. It was so so difficult to pay attention.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because of the readings we did outside of class. I found that getting to pick our own book for our group book critique was nice because it allowed us to find something that we were really interested in. I personally felt that I learned a lot from the book that we chose and appreciate the flexibility. However, the class sessions themselves were often just a summary of the readings, sometimes requiring us to simply regurgitate what we read via a presentation and then present it to the class without any analysis or time to talk. It might have been more intellectually stimulating if there were more lectures with specific detail that were balanced with more guided discussions in smaller groups. There didn't seem to be a lot of case studies that we went over that weren't touched on in the readings. A wider spread of activities could have also been interesting, like a guest lecture or a different project instead of 4 papers.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved how each team worked together to share diverse ideas! The presentations were all very creative and I felt that I learned a lot because of how interactive we were with others.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Although it is a required class for the MMS certificate, I would recommend it to any student because of how stimulating and relevant it is to the world we live in.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Know that this is an urban planning course if taken with Sam Veraldi, not a business/consulting style capstone course. Lots of outside work, but very little in class work / time since only once a week. Three books + critiques, a few readings, four 4-page assignments, and a final team project + paper -- it was a lot. Class time should be used better, a lot of time wasted in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: take it, but be warned, its a lot of work for one class

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It really doesn't align with the rest of the MMS curriculum. I'm not sure why an urban planning class is the capstone. If you have to take it you can tough it out. But it is extremely boring.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a lot of work. The workload in it of itself is fine, however, the way that the class is taught can be incredibly frustrating. While the topic itself is very interesting, the group that you get has a big impact on your experience. While the professor is nice, he does not always seem responsive to students that ask for feedback and it is difficult to tell if he is actually reading all of the work we do, which is frustrating because there is a lot of it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely would recommend having a finance background, and if not, then to study enough to where you can understand the nuanced concepts that are covered in the majority of the class. The smart technology is interesting, and its applications are cool so that element of the class was thought-provoking and enjoyable to learn/present on.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Strap in because you will have a lot of work but Professor Veraldi gives you all the resources and help you need to be successful
